    Development and Therapeutic Potential of NUAKs Inhibitors

    • Muhammad Faisal
      Muhammad Faisal
      Division of Bio-Medical Science & Technology, KIST School, University of Science and Technology (UST), Hwarangno 14-gil 5, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    NUAK isoforms, NUAK1 (ARK5) and NUAK2 (SNARK), are important members of the AMPK family of protein kinases. They are involved in a broad spectrum of physiological and cellular events, and sometimes their biological roles overlap. NUAK isoform dysregulation is associated with numerous pathological disorders, including neurodegeneration, metastatic cancer, and diabetes. Therefore, they are promising therapeutic targets in metabolic diseases and cancers; consequently, various NUAK-targeted inhibitors have been disclosed. The first part of this review comprises a brief discussion of the homology, expression, structure, and characteristics of NUAK isoforms. The second part focuses on NUAK isoforms’ involvement in crucial biological operations, including mechanistic findings, highlighting how their abnormal functioning contributes to disease progression and quality of life. The third part summarizes the key findings and applications of targeting NUAK isoforms for treating multiple cancers and neurodegenerative disorders. The final part systematically presents a critical review and analysis of the literature on NUAK isoform inhibitions through small molecules.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Protein kinases catalyze the reversible hydroxyl-phosphorylation reaction of Thr, Ser, or Tyr residues of protein substrates. Generally, they themselves are substrates of upstream protein kinases or have the ability to autophosphorylate, which plays a critical role in a signaling cascade. More precisely, they act as sensors that play a crucial role in signaling pathways and show stimulus to stress conditions, osmolarity, nutrient availability, temperature, and light.(1,2) Most kinase signaling pathways are very complex as they control numerous cellular operations, for instance, differentiation, cell growth, immune responses, and gene transcription.(3) Therefore, elucidating kinase signaling pathways in health and diseases has become a key area in cell biology research.
    On the basis of the catalytic domain, protein kinases have been categorized as tyrosine kinases (90 kinases) and serine/threonine (Ser/Thr) kinases (388 kinases).(4) The catalytic kinase domain bears 12 conserved subdomains that fold into a common catalytic core skeleton. The AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) subfamily has 12 members: MARK1, MARK2, MARK3, MARK4, MELK, QIK, QSK, salt-inducible kinase (SIK), BRSK1, BRSK2, NUAK1, and NUAK2.(4) The AMPKs perform important biological operations such as resolution of the immune system,(5) regulating gene transcription,(5,6) controlling cell polarity (MARKs and BRSKs),(7,8) and maintaining cellular energy levels (AMPKα).(9)
    The NUAK1 [aka. OMPHK1 or ARK5] and closely related NUAK2 [aka. OMPHK2 or SNARK], which are phosphorylated and activated by the LKB1 (liver kinase B1; aka. STK11) tumor suppressor protein kinase, are Ser/Thr kinases that are important in cancer progression, cell adhesion, cell proliferation, and metastasis, as well as carbohydrate metabolism.(10) Previous investigations have shown that NUAK isoforms (aka. NUAKs) participate in a number of significant functions such as neuronal polarity and axon branching,(11) senescence,(12) cell adhesion,(13,14) and controlling embryonic development.(15,16) NUAKs also function as a survival factor in MYC-driven tumors,(17) promote cancer cell invasion,(18−20) and control cell division via their ability to stimulate proliferation.(21) Owing to their key functions in cellular signaling, their dysregulation has been found to be associated with numerous serious disorders such as infectious disorders and cancers.(22) Therefore, NUAKs have presented a very promising prospect for targeted treatment using inhibitors.
    This review discusses the specific characteristics of NUAKs and recent advances made to understand their signaling connections in tumor cells. It also covers the intricate biological operations of NUAKs in cell migration, invasion, adhesion, proliferation, metabolism, senescence, apoptosis, and survival. In addition, the review highlights genetic mouse models that have been employed to elucidate the roles of NUAKs in metabolic homeostasis, tumorigenesis, actin stress fiber remodeling, muscle-specific knockout, global knockout, and omphalocele as well as to elucidate how the dysregulation of NUAKs is strongly linked with a diverse range of diseases. Further, it discusses the value of NUAKs as potential, interesting, and novel therapeutic targets to tackle cancers and neurodegenerative diseases and summarizes the results of NUAKs inhibitors that have been successfully developed and utilized for the treatment of diseases. Finally, the application of pyrimidine, indole, staurosporinone, thiazole, pyrazole, and imidazole derivatives as small-molecule inhibitors of NUAKs has been reviewed by comparing their inhibitory potencies with each other.

    2. Homology, Expression, Structure, and Specific Characteristics of NUAK Isoforms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. NUAK1 (ARK5)

    NUAK1 is of particular interest as various reports in the literature have shown its involvement in a broad spectrum of processes.(12,19,23,24) NUAK1 belongs to a group of 12 protein kinases closely related to the energy sensor AMPK subunits α1 and α2. These protein kinases have been generally grouped as AMPK-related kinases or AMPK subfamily and employ two different mechanisms to recognize their physiological substrates: (i) proximal mode, where the active site of the protein kinase recognizes the consensus phosphorylation sequence in the protein substrate; (ii) distal mode, a domain on substrate protein is recognized by a recognition/cognate domain on kinase molecules.(25,26)
    With regard to amino acid units, human NUAK1 has 661 (MW ≈ 76 kDa), whereas mouse NUAK1 has 658. Further, kinase domains of human and mouse NUAK1 are 100% identical at the amino-acid sequence level (Figure 1A).(15) NUAK1 also has the highest homology to NUAK2; i.e., human NUAK1 amino acid sequence shows 58% homology to NUAK2 as a whole and 82% in the kinase domain.(24) Like all AMPK-related kinases, NUAK1 has a highly conserved T-loop and a critical threonine residue in the catalytic domain. STK11, an upstream serine-threonine kinase, strongly activates the AMPK subfamily, with the exemption of MELK, in vitro by phosphorylating their conserved T-loop threonine residue (Figure 1B).(27) For full activation of STK11 kinase potency and subsequent substrate activation, a complex to stabilize and localize STK11 in the cytoplasm must be developed using MO25-like protein and a pseudokinase STRAD (sterile-20-related adaptor).(27) Endogenous efficacy of the AMPK subfamily is dramatically reduced in cells that do not express STK11 or where STK11 was previously depleted, revealing that STK11 is a limiting factor in AMPK subfamily activation, at least in vitro.(26,27) Other studies have indicated that protein kinase B (PKB; aka. AKT) activates NUAK1 by phosphorylating it at serine 600.(28) Currently, it is uncertain whether, like AMPK, NUAK1 requires partner proteins or dimerization for activity. However, recent evidence about the structure and activation of members of the PAR/MARK class has indicated that they have the ability of autoactivation,(29) and this might be true for other associated kinases. Another AMPK-related kinase, viz. MELK, has intrinsic potency and is able to autophosphorylate without activation by STK11.(27)
    AMPK is a component of the stress response system of cells. As its yeast homologue sucrose nonfermenting 1 (SNF1), AMPK expression is induced by diverse cell stresses such as glucose deprivation, hypoxia, or an increased intracellular AMP/ATP ratio.(30) AMPK induction by cellular stresses and further activation by STK11 phosphorylation trigger a signaling cascade that works through inactivation of mTOR to switch off cellular anabolic pathways and prepare the cell for energy storage restoration via catabolic metabolism.(31)
    In an investigation to assess the global NUAK1 mouse knockout, expression was assessed by in situ hybridization to observe mRNA levels and by βgal insertion into the NUAK1 gene.(15) The two approaches correlated well and revealed that mRNA levels should be a precise indicator of protein expression in adult tissues. On embryonic day 9.5, expression of βgal was observed throughout the undifferentiated neuroectoderm, and it mostly occurred in the epidermis; having said that, it was greatly expressed in the ventral body wall (VBW). On E18.5 and E14.5, expression of βgal was only noticed in differentiated areas of the cortex but not in other brain parts, and it was maintained in the epidermis of the entire body. An early investigation on NUAK1 activation in rat skeletal muscle reported the expression profile in adult tissues and observed mRNA present in skeletal muscle, liver, brain, kidney, and heart.(32,33)

    2.2. NUAK2 (SNARK)

    NUAK2 is a serine/threonine-protein kinase comprising 661 amino acid units (MW ≈ 76 kDa) in human protein. It was initially observed in 2001 as a UV-induced gene in rat keratinocytes.(34) Within the AMPK-related kinases, NUAK2 is most closely related with NUAK1. These two kinases differ from the rest in the AMPK subfamily in that they lack an ubiquitin-associated (UBA) protein domain after the C-terminus of the kinase domain.(35) Despite the fact that mammals have two distinct genes, Caenorhabditis elegans has a unique ortholog, UNC-82,(36) which reveals that NUAK1 and NUAK2 are likely to be derived from a common ancestor gene, and hence, they could still share interaction partners and cellular functions.(27)
    It has been observed that NUAK2 is the only AMPK subfamily that responds to several cellular stresses.(26) Its expression in several cell lines is induced by nutrient deprivation, such as hypoxia conditions, glutamine, or glucose deficiency, or increased reactive oxygen molecules.(37) However, numerous investigations have highlighted the fact that unlike AMPK, its response to cellular stress seems to be highly cell context and cell type dependent.(27,34,37) In human myocyte cultures, its expression is induced by palmitate and TNFα, which are two stress substances involved in the acquisition of insulin resistance by skeletal muscle cells.(38) Although it was observed that this insulin resistance was independent of NUAK2 status, there is available information that indicates that NUAK2 participates in skeletal muscle metabolism homeostasis, and that it mediates part of the exercise-stimulated glucose transport.(26,39)

    3. NUAK Isoforms’ Biological Operations, Mechanistic Findings, and Association with Diseases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. Cell Invasion and Migration

    An initial investigation that highlights NUAK1’s involvement in cell migration was performed in human pancreatic cancer cell lines (PANC-1). NUAK1 overexpression in PANC-1 cell lines considerably increases their invasive capability, which is attenuated by PKB inhibition and promoted by IGF-1 stimulation, indicating a PKB/IGF regulatory mode. The mechanism by which NUAK1 contributes in cell invasion is found to include enhanced potency of matrixin-9 and matrixin-2 (MMP-9 and MMP-2), as a greater affinity of these two matrixins is observed in NUAK1 overexpressing PANC-1 cell lines. Additionally, the enhanced cell invasion upon NUAK1 overexpression has also been verified in vivo.(28) Subcutaneous tumors that originated from transplantation of PANC-1 cell lines stably overexpressing NUAK1 highly invade muscularis propria, and metastases at multiple organs is also noticed at the initial stages, compared with PANC-1 cell lines expressing endogenous levels of NUAK1.(20,40−42)
    Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) signaling through suppressor of mothers against decapentaplegic (SMAD) proteins and protein kinase pathways is observed to down- or up-regulate the expression of various genes and, therefore, influences physiological functions, such as invasion, migration, apoptosis, cell cycle arrest, and differentiation.(43)NUAK isoforms are identified to be two TGF-β target genes. That is to say, transcriptional induction of NUAK isoforms by TGF-β produces signaling loops in such a way that NUAK2 promotes, while NUAK1 inhibits, biological actions mediated by TGF-β signaling. Thus, the balance between the apparently opposite functions of both isoforms of NUAK on TGF-β signaling can perform significant processes in mesenchymal and epithelial cell physiology.(44)

    3.2. Cell Adhesion

    A proteomic analysis performed on immune-precipitated NUAK1 has identified interactors belonging to the myosin light-chain phosphatase complex (aka. MYPT1-PP1β-NUAK1 complex and PP1βMYPT1 myosin phosphatase complex), which are accountable for catalyzing dephosphorylation (removal of a phosphate species from protein) of proteins, for example, PLK1 (polo-like kinase-1) and MLC2 (myosin light chain 2), which in turn regulates many processes including cell adhesion and smooth muscle contraction.(14) The PP1βMYPT1 myosin phosphatase complex is formed using catalytic species denoted by protein phosphatase type 1β (PP1β), and two regulatory subunits: (i) M20, having an unknown function, and (ii) myosin phosphatase target subunit 1 (MYPT1). NUAK1 interacts with the complex formed by MYPT1 and PP1β, and phosphorylates the former at three distinct sites (Ser910, Ser472, and Ser445) to enhance binding between MYPT1 and 14-3-3 protein, leading to the inhibition of the PP1βMYPT1 myosin phosphatase complex.(14) Since MYPT1 phosphorylation is decreased in cell lines with STK11 deletion, the described role of NUAK1 was investigated to be influenced by the upstream kinase STK11. Furthermore, inhibition of the PP1βMYPT1 myosin phosphatase complex followed by activation of the STK11/NUAK1 axis results in greater levels of MLC2 phosphorylation, promoting cell detachment (Figure 2).(14) Additionally, the investigation also identified the existence of a GILK (Gly-Ile-Leu-Lys) unit in the NUAK1 sequence, which mediates direct binding to a regulatory pocket on the surface of PP1β. Noteworthy, NUAK2 is also described to have the GILK unit and to cooperate with the PP1β-MYPT1, sharing similar phosphorylation sites with NUAK1 on MYPT1, thus supporting previous research studies that indicate MYPT1 phosphorylation by NUAK2.(14,45) The recent investigation of Zagórska and co-workers has also shown that NUAKs are the only kinases of the class, which are able to interact with PP1β-MYPT1.(42,46)

    3.3. Glucose Transport and Metabolism

    Skeletal muscle has a fundamentally significant part in the maintaining normal glucose homeostasis and in controlling whole-body carbohydrate metabolism. Glucose generally delivers energy sources for tissues of the body. Exercise and insulin are the chief stimulators of glucose transport in muscle cells.(26) It is widely known that in situations of insulin resistance such as adult-onset diabetes, involving reduced insulin-stimulated glucose transport, exercise is extremely valuable because it enhances glucose uptake and transport in SkMC, in addition to insulin sensitivity and fatty acid oxidation.(47) Exercise and insulin stimulation of glucose transport act via distinct signaling pathways; however, their signaling converge at the PKB substrates paralogs, AS160 (aka. TBC1D4) and TBC1D1, enhancing their phosphorylation and assisting to increase the translocation of the glucose transporter type 4 (GLUT4) from vesicles to the cytoplasmic membrane.(48)
    Investigations using muscle-specific STK11 knockout mice have analyzed STK11 as a significant molecular regulator of contraction-stimulated glucose transport. In mice, STK11 depletion in SkMC has reduced fatty acid oxidation during treadmill exercise and reduced contraction-stimulated glucose transport.(49) Also, these mice have decreased AMPK-α2 (the predominant AMPK component in muscle) and lower phosphorylation of TBC1D1 and AS160.(50) Despite the fact that AMPK-α2 is significantly decreased, and is believed to be the exclusive substrate of STK11 involved in glucose metabolism, further investigations using mice lacking AMPK-α2 have revealed that AMPK cannot be the sole substrate of STK11 involved in contraction-stimulated glucose transport. Mice lacking AMPK-α2 only have partially reduced fatty acid oxidation and little or no change in exercise-dependent glucose uptake and transport stimulation.(51,52) These outcomes have revealed that in muscle cells, STK11 regulation of glucose homeostasis probably involves more than one member of the AMPK-related kinases besides AMPK-α2.(26)
    It is interesting to note that NUAK2 heterozygous knockout mice display premature onset of obesity and diabetes mellitus (DM) along with enhanced hyperinsulinemia, hyperglycemia, and fat mass: all classic features of glucose intolerance (GI) and adult-onset diabetes.(39,53) Furthermore, these mice display decreased contraction-stimulated glucose transport when investigated for treadmill exercise, and myocytes (i.e., muscle cells) derived from these mice have reduced TBC1D1 phosphorylation.(39) On the same note, mice expressing a dominant negative mutant NUAK2 have impaired contraction-stimulated glucose transport in SkMC. NUAK2 is a specific STK11 substrate that controls contraction-stimulated glucose transport.(39) Along with these reports, obese patients also have enhanced NUAK2 levels in muscle cells, and when human myocyte cell cultures are exposed to palmitate and TNFα (agents that induce insulin resistance), NUAK2 strongly increases.(38) Attainment of insulin resistance is independent of NUAK2 levels, because reduction of NUAK2 does not revert insulin resistance, revealing that NUAK2 induction in obese humans is highly expected to be a response to counterbalance insulin resistance effects by enhancing exercise-dependent glucose uptake and transport.(38)
    In adult tissues, it is not possible to evaluate the physiological functions of the kinase attributed to the embryonic lethality of NUAK1 global knockout mice; therefore, investigations have been accompanied by the use of conditional tissue-specific gene deletions.(32) To date, only one study has disclosed a skeletal muscle-specific NUAK1 knockout (MNUAK1KO) by deletion of the kinase using crerecombinase under the control of the muscle phosphocreatine kinase promoter.(54) No basal-like phenotype was noticed, revealing that deleting NUAK1 in muscle has no important developmental effect. However, on a high fat diet, MNUAK1KO mice has a higher concentration of muscle glycogen, higher insulin sensitivity, greater glucose tolerance, and lower fasting blood glucose level than control mice.(54) Furthermore, phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS-1) at Ser-1097 is significantly reduced in NUAK1-deficient muscle, and insulin signaling is improved in the soleus muscle of MNUAK1KO mice, suggesting that a physiological function of NUAK1 is to suppress glucose uptake through negative regulation of insulin signaling in oxidative muscle, possibly via the phosphorylation of IRS1.(33)

    3.4. Cell Senescence and Proliferation

    NUAK1 has been engaged in controlling senescence and cell ploidy.(12) It has been observed that down-regulation of NUAK1 enhances the replicative potential of senescent cells. Further study reveals that NUAK1-induced senescence is related to its function in the control of cell ploidy. Particularly, NUAK1 is observed to cause aneuploidy through the negative regulation of the large tumor suppressor kinase 1 (LATS1) protein levels, known to promote cytokinesis.(12,42)
    Although NUAK1 has been indicated to have contradictory biological roles of an inhibitor or promoter of cell division progression, it has been identified to participate in controlling cell proliferation.(42) That is to say, it has been observed to interact with and phosphorylate p53 at Ser392 and Ser15, which causes p21 induction (aka. WAF1 and CAP20) and cell division cycle arrests at the G1/S checkpoint.(21) In contrast, Alessi and co-workers suggest that NUAK1 is a positive regulator of cell cycle.(46) In their investigation, inhibiting NUAK1 potency using HTH-01-015 5, a selective and potent NUAK1 inhibitor, reduced the proportion of cells in the S-phase of the cell division cycle and restricted the development of the mitotic phase. A more detailed examination of the mechanism reveals a remarkable interplay between NUAK1, SCFβTrCP (Skp, Cullin and F-boxβTrCP) E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, Polo like kinase 1 (PLK1) and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK). That is to say, inhibiting the phosphatase potency of the MYPT1-PP1β complex upon induction of NUAK1 increases potency to conduct G2/M transition and PLK1 phosphorylation. Moreover, active PLK1 phosphorylates NUAK1 at two conserved noncatalytic serine residues (Ser480 and Ser476). This induces binding of NUAK1 to βTrCP, the substrate-recognition subunit of the SCFβTrCP E3 ligase, leading to ubiquitylation and degradation of NUAK1 (Figure 3A). Therefore, during the different phases of cell cycle, reciprocal modulation of NUAK1 and PLK1 levels is indicated to orchestrate cell-division cycle progression.(46) Further investigation indicates a positive function of NUAK1 in the regulation of cell cycle as its down-regulation results in cell cycle arrest,(55) and its overexpression has been demonstrated to increase proliferation.(56)
    In a recent interesting study, STK11 and NUAK1 are observed to have phosphatase and tensin homologue-synthetic sick/lethal (PTEN-SSL) patterns of activity in the PTEN-deficient cancer cells. Moreover, in PTEN-deficient cancers, NUAK1 and STK11 are selectively fundamental for the progression of the cell cycle and repairing damaged DNA (Figure 3B).(57) PTEN-deficient cancer cell lines have impaired DNA damage repair and also have enhanced cell proliferation via accelerated progression of cell cycle. In these cells, losing STK11 function would decrease its NUAK1 phosphorylation at Thr211 and therefore deactivate the p53-regulated brake on progression of cell cycle. However, Ser600 phosphorylation by the PKB(AKT)/PTEN pathway would continue to assist progression of the cell cycle via an STK11-independent mechanism (Figure 3B, upper model in (iii)). Hence, in these cells, the net effect of losing STK11 would be further cell cycle acceleration. Meanwhile, loss of STK11 would suppress the DNA damage repair (Figure 3B, lower model in (iii)). Hypothetically, this combination of phenomena (increased DNA damage or accelerated cell cycle progression) would result in senescence or cell death.(57)
    The understanding that ARK5 can activate and phosphorylate large tumor suppressor kinase 1 (LATS1) associates it to a highly conserved growth regulating signaling pathway, viz. Hippo, which is shown to be involved in organ size control.(32,58) Also, Hippo signaling exerts a significant role in controlling cell proliferation and contributes to the progression of numerous disorders including tumor. The transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) and transcriptional coactivators Yes-associated protein (YAP) is the main end target of the Hippo pathway, which in turn maintains the expression of genes number (Figure 4). YAP overexpression is capable of mimicking the loss of Hippo signaling and creating enormously oversized organs. When overexpressed in mouse liver, it also leads to HCC.(59) NUAK isoforms are observed to be able to directly phosphorylate LATS1 resulting in degradation of LATS1,(12) which is investigated to result in enhanced activity of YAP/TAZ, thereby causing an increase in organ size and proliferation.(60) This implies that the existence of NUAK isoforms would be pro-proliferative.(32) However, other data in human cell lines have reflected that LATS1 down-regulation produces irreversible cell cycle arrest in normal human cells, revealing an antiproliferative role for NUAK1.(12,61) In the support of primary findings that NUAK1 activity assists proliferation, various other studies have been performed in the past few years, at least in certain cancer models including HCC,(62) nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC),(63) glioma,(20) and breast.(40) Moreover, in an interesting study, NUAK1 is reported to be able to direct phosphorylate and regulate p53, resulting in cell cycle arrest.(21) However, no such mechanism has since been documented in spite of several other validated upstream kinases of p53 and various publications investigating its function in cell proliferation.(64) NUAK1 may contribute to maintain the balance between metastasis and tumor growth, and can control adhesion in melanoma cells and, but it is not clear if it has a anti- or pro-proliferative effect.(18)
    On the flip side, MARK1/4 are indicated to assist activation of LATS1.(65) Adding complexity to this model (Figure 4), in response to energetic stress, AMPK has been recently shown by three independent moieties to suppress YAP activity.(66−68) An earlier report described STK11-dependent regulation of YAP, independent of either LATS or AMPK, indicating that additional ARKs contribute in the regulation of this pathway.(69) Undoubtedly, the Hippo pathway is intersected by the STK11 pathway at multiple levels, and it will be interesting to investigate how this regulation is coordinated and certainly if it is bidirectional.
    Very recently, NUAK2 is identified as a positive regulator of YAP/TAZ activity that directly inhibits LATS-based YAP/TAZ phosphorylation. Induction of NUAK2 by AP-1 and YAP/TAZ is needed for vigorous YAP/TAZ signaling.(70) Moreover, pharmacological NUAK2 inactivation, blocking expression with RNAi (RNA interference) or knocking out NUAK2 with CRISPR inhibits YAP/TAZ transcriptional potency, reduces tumor growth, drives cytoplasmic localization of YAP/TAZ, and decreases the growth of diverse cancer cell lines, altogether identifying a positive feed-forward loop in the Hippo pathway and demonstrating a key function for NUAK2 in enhancing YAP/TAZ oncogenic function (Figure 4). In a related study, NUAK2 has been investigated as a crucial mediator of YAP-driven hepatomegaly and liver tumorigenesis.(71) It is selectively demanded for YAP-driven growth and contributes in a feedback loop to maximize potency of YAP through promoting activity of myosins and actin polymerization. In addition, pharmacological NUAK2 inactivation suppresses YAP-dependent liver overgrowth and cancer cell proliferation. Therefore, NUAK2 illustrates an actionable moiety within the pathway that could be amenable to target Hippo/YAP signaling.

    3.5. Cell Survival and Apoptosis

    NUAK2 is observed to aid in maintaining skeletal muscle mass.(26) Adult mice and humans have shown enhanced expression of NUAK2 in response to metabolic stress and aging skeletal muscle. Noteworthy, the loss of NUAK2 has enhanced the sensitivity of myocyte cell cultures to palmitate-induced apoptosis.(72) Furthermore, mice bearing a muscle-specific NUAK2 dominant negative mutant kinase (SDN) have severe muscle fiber atrophy. Interestingly, Lessard and co-workers have shown that these mice have impaired Rho signaling because they have reduced expression of downstream Rho signaling targets and reduced MYPT1 phosphorylation at the Rho kinase Thr696 phosphorylation site, revealing that defective Rho signaling might have participated in the apoptosis of phenotypes upon NUAK2 loss.(72) Using in vitro profiling, primary myocytes cell cultures obtained from SDN mice also presented the same data. Exposing myocytes to palmitate enhances MYPT1 phosphorylation, and this effect is lost when NUAK2 is depleted from the cells.(72) It is widely identified that Rho/ROCK (Rho-associated kinase) signaling participates in apoptosis since it is demanded for cell detachment and development of apoptotic bodies.(73) Constitutive ROCK activation is performed by cysteine aspartases which cut the regulatory domain at the C-terminus of the kinase. ROCK overactivation enhances bud formation (characteristic of apoptotic cells) and cell contraction, along with cell detachment. ROCK inhibitors have been utilized as tumor therapy drugs as tumor cells utilize ROCK overactivation to rearrange their cytoskeleton and obtain metastatic and invasion cell properties.(73) NUAK2 can serve as a connecting protein between actin SFs remodeling and apoptosis cascade.
    The protective function of NUAK2 in cell survival has been analyzed in tumor cells resistant to Fas (CD95)-induced apoptosis.(74) Tumor cells resistant to Fas-induced apoptosis have also exhibited enhanced motility and invasiveness via activation of NFκB genes. NUAK2 is seen as one of the Fas-induced up-regulated genes, and its overexpression has protected cells from Fas-induced apoptosis in an NF-κB dependent fashion. Tumor cells lacking NUAK2 are more responsive to Fas apoptosis, and have displayed a reduced invasiveness capability and motility.(26,74)

    3.6. Maintaining Metabolic Homeostasis and Spliceosome Activity

    Along with biological roles in cell senescence, proliferation, adhesion, invasion, and migration, NUAK1 promotes the survival of MYC-overexpressing cells and regulates metabolic homeostasis.(17) Particularly, NUAK1 is found in a synthetic lethality screening performed to search for genes for which the loss of function is lethal only in the existence of MYC-overexpression. Apart from the interesting finding that NUAK1 depletion results in cell death of MYC-overexpressing cells, the investigation confirms several past studies; for example, a cell cycle arrest in the synthesis phase (S-phase) upon NUAK1 depletion; however, most significantly, it reveals new roles in maintaining metabolic homeostasis. To be more precise, NUAK1 participates in controlling ATP levels via two main mechanisms: (i) inhibiting the mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1) pathway. Briefly, activating MYC enhances AMPK induction and reduces mTOR complex 1 activity. NUAK1 depletion, however, ablates the enhancement in AMPK potency, leading to an improvement of overall protein synthesis, perhaps attributed to the incapability of AMPK to restrain mTOR complex 1. Treatment with sirolimus (aka. Rapamycin, an acute inhibitor of mTOR complex 1) can prevent cell death by providing relief from metabolic stress caused by NUAK1 depletion, thus confirming that NUAK1 participates in cell survival by restraining mTOR complex 1 potency; (ii) promoting the expression of components of the mitochondrial respiratory chain (MRC). That is to say, NUAK1 sustains metabolic homeostasis by maintaining the MRC, as NUAK1 depletion significantly reduces the expression of multiple components of the ETC (electron transport chain). Moreover, a study of a tumor model involving the transplantation of HCC cells expressing MYC showed that the down-regulation of NUAK1 not only reduces the occurrence of tumor development but also increases mice survival compared with that of the NUAK1 wild-type (WT) counterpart.(17) Hence, the overall investigation suggests significant implications of NUAK1 in metabolism and proposes NUAK1 inhibition as a promising therapeutic and diagnostic target to treat cancer patients.(42)
    In a recent interesting study, the synthetic lethal interaction between MYC and NUAK1, and the role of Ca2+ in supporting tumor cell viability have been investigated.(75) More precisely, in cancer cells lacking STK11, NUAK1 potency is regulated by an alternate approach that involves Ca2+-dependent PKCα activation (Figure 5A). Ca2+/PKCα-dependent activation of NUAK1 assists engagement of the TORC1-AMPK metabolic checkpoint, thus shielding tumor cells from MYC-based cell death, and indeed, MYC selects for increased Ca2+ signaling in part by transcriptional regulation of ITPR and PKCα. Notably, calcium-dependent activation of the mTORC1-AMPK metabolic checkpoint demands both NUAK1 and PKCα, and hence, suppression of either drives pronounced HeLa cell apoptosis, thus revealing a positive function for this pathway in maintaining tumor.
    Very recently, NUAK1 has been observed to be associated with the splicing machinery.(76) That is to say, phosphatase 1 nuclear targeting subunit (PNUTS), a regulatory subunit of PP1, binds chromatin in part through its interaction with nascent RNA. Consequently, PNUTS comes under the contact of chromatin-linked NUAK1, and its interaction with nascent RNA is stabilized via NUAK1-based phosphorylation. This stabilization locally incapacitates PP1 potency toward spliceosomal proteins and permits activation of spliceosome (Figure 5B). NUAK1 inhibition eliminates chromatin interaction of PNUTS, decreases activity of spliceosome, and suppresses synthesis of nascent RNA. Activating MYC does not circumvent the requirement for NUAK1 for activity of spliceosome but considerably attenuates transcription termination. As consequence, inhibition of NUAK1 in cells expressing high MYC levels induces global accumulation of RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) both at the first exon-intron boundary and at the pause site but does not enhance synthesis of mRNA, suggesting that inhibiting NUAK1 in the existence of deregulated MYC traps nonproductive RNAPII on account of the lack of properly gathered spliceosomes.(76)

    3.7. Actin Stress Fibers Remodeling

    There are currently only two known proteins that physically interact with NUAK2. These proteins regulate the MLC phosphorylation cycle at the actin stress fibers (SFs) of smooth muscle cells. Alterations in the ATPase potency of MLC remodels the actin SFs changing contractility and motility of cells.(77) Enhanced MLC phosphorylation leads to high contraction of the actin bundles, followed by cell detachment and enhanced motility of cells.(26) This phosphorylation is typically regulated by Rho kinases, which are serine/threonine-protein kinases that are activated by an upstream small GTPase, RhoA.(77) Myosin light-chain phosphatase (MLCP), which consist of a phosphatase catalytic subunit (PP1) and a phosphatase regulatory subunit (MYPT1), desphosphorylates MLC. The RhoA and MLCP are recruited to actin SFs by the myosin phosphatase Rho-interacting protein (MRIP).(78)
    MRIP also recruits NUAK2 to the same position.(13) This interaction is demanded for NUAK2 to inhibit the function of the phosphatase regulatory subunit (MYPT1). The fact that existence of NUAK2 at the actin SFs, which prevents MLC dephosphorylation, is believed to be somewhat kinase-independent, as an inactive kinase mutant, NUAK2 has succeeded to inhibit the action of phosphatase.(13) Nonetheless, an independent investigation has also displayed that NUAK2 can directly bind and phosphorylate MYPT1,(45) implying that NUAK2 may also inhibit the phosphatase in a kinase-dependent fashion. In a related study, the closely related NUAK1 has also been shown to physically interact with the catalytic subunit PP1 of the MLCP complex, where it inactivates the phosphatase by directly phosphorylating the Ser910, Ser472, and Ser445 residues of MYPT1, and all distinct sites other than those commonly phosphorylated by ROCK (Thr853 and Thr696).(14) MYPT1 phosphorylation recruits the phosphatase to scaffold 14-3-3 proteins which traps and keeps the phosphatase away from the actin SFs, and hence, avoids MLC dephosphorylation.(14,79) These somewhat different models reveal that NUAKs may collaborate or have redundant functions at the actin SFs. In both cases, the existence of NUAKs at the actin SFs enhances cell motility, cell detachment, and turnover by keeping phosphorylated the MLC (Figure 6A).(13,79,80) On the same note, another investigation has displayed that NUAK2 overexpression in a human cancer cell line leads to acute cell–cell detachment when the cells are exposed to a glucose-free environment.(26,81) Moreover, in a recent interesting study, it is shown that YAP/TAZ-based transcription is demanded to modulate cytoskeletal tension generation and enable persistent cell motility (Figure 6B). This pathway is defined as a negative feedback system through which Rho-ROCK-myosin II activate TAZ and YAP, limiting activation of myosin II via expression of NUAK2.(82)

    3.8. Axon Branching and Cortical Development

    Very recent data has emerged displaying that NUAK1 can have other roles in different tissues,for example, controlling axon branching by interfering with mitochondrial transport. In axons, the NUAK1-STK11 pathway maintains mitochondria immobilization, and NUAK1 and STK11 are essential and enough to immobilize the mitochondria, especially at sites of nascent presynaptic.(11) Furthermore, an interesting study indicated that NUAK1 is haplo-insufficient in mice with regard to its biological operation in the formation of cortical connectivity, and that loss-of-function mutations in NUAK1 contributes to the etiology of neurodevelopmental diseases.(83) That is to say, it has been observed that inactivating one allele of the NUAK1 gene leads to a complex phenotype such as reduced terminal axon branching of cortico-cortical projections, defective axonal mitochondria trafficking, and growth retardation. Most importantly, NUAK1 heterozygosity reduces the prepulse inhibition of the acoustic startle reflex, modifies the preference for social novelty without influencing conspecific social preference, and results in disruption of numerous cognitive courses. Hence, NUAK1 haploinsufficiency results in defects in the formation of cortical connectivity and in a complex range of behavioral deficits.

    3.9. Functions of NUAKs with Starvin/BAG3 in Autophagic Protein Turnover

    In postmitotic cells, the inability to remove protein aggregates such as neurons or muscles is a cellular hallmark of aging cells and is a crucial element in the initiation and progression of protein-misfolding diseases. In a recent interesting study, a novel role of NUAKs with the Stv-Hsc70-4 complex in the autophagic protein clearance in muscle tissue has been reported. To be more precise, loss of NUAKs causes cellular degeneration attributed to the abnormal accumulation of certain proteins, including CryAB and filamin (Fil). NUAKs genetically and biochemically interact with Drosophila Starvin (Stv), the ortholog of mammalian Bcl-2-associated athanogene 3 (BAG3). Consistent with a known role for the cochaperone BAG3 and the heat shock cognate 71 kDa (Hsc70; aka. HSPA8) ATPase in the autophagic clearance of proteins, RNAi of Drosophila Stv, Hsc70-4, or autophagy-related 8a (Atg8a) all exhibit muscle degeneration and muscle contraction defects that phenocopy NUAK mutants (Figure 7). Furthermore, Fil is a target of NUAKs kinase activity and abnormally accumulates upon loss of the BAG3-Hsc70-4 complex.(148) Additionally, Atg8a, ref(2)p/p62, and ubiquitin (Ub) are enhanced in regions of protein aggregation, consistent with a block in autophagy upon knocking out NUAKs.

    4. Clinical Applications of Inhibiting NUAK Isoforms and Further Discussion on the Association of NUAK Isoforms with Diseases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    NUAK isoforms (aka. NUAKs) control numerous processes such as embryonic development,(15,16) cell adhesion,(13,14) cell division,(21) cell proliferation, replicative senescence and ploidy,(12) cell migration and invasion,(28) neuronal polarity and axon branching,(11) actin SFs remodeling, metabolic homeostasis, survival of MYC-overexpressing cells,(17) muscle growth and myosin organization,(84) glycogen synthesis and carbohydrate metabolism,(54) and TAU stability.(85) Therefore, abnormal functioning of NUAKs has been causally linked to numerous disorders. Summarily, NUAK isoforms have been connected with tumor cell survival, metastasis, and invasion, and poor prognosis in numerous tumors, including NSCLC,(63) melanoma,(18) breast, glioma,(20,40) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).(62) In human cancer, NUAK1 gene alteration frequency is comparatively less than most AMPK subunits.(60) More precisely, in 164 investigations (45709 samples) conducted, its highest alteration frequency was 18% in neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC). According to cbioportal.org, its alteration frequency was less than 7% in all other cancers. Nonetheless, compared with that of the nontumor tissue, immunohistochemistry (IHC) of the human tissue displayed high levels of NUAK1 expression in HCC (66% of patient samples), pancreatic cancer (57%), and colon cancer (38%).(17) It has been observed that NUAK1 expression is much higher in liver metastasis and enlarged in more advanced cases of colorectal cancer (CRC).(86) Further, NUAK1 has been associated with numerous tumorigenic functions; for example, promotion of tumor cell invasion and metastasis by enhancing the expression of matrixins (MT1-MMP, MMP-9, and MMP-2) downstream of protein kinase B (PKB).(87) Matrixins perform a crucial part in degrading the basement membrane and extracellular matrix (ECM), and therefore, enhance angiogenesis and metastasis in various cancer types.(88) Accordingly, fixing NUAKs can result in treatment of numerous diseases, which is discussed in detail in this section.

    4.1. Alzheimer’s Disease and Dementia

    Common neurodegenerative disorders, such as dementia, Alzheimer’s, and Parkinson’s, partially result from unusual accumulation of various proteins in the brain. When certain proteins accumulate in the brain, they become toxic, making the brain susceptible to degeneration. TAU is a protein associated with dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. Hence, taking a drug that stops TAU collection in the brain can assist in delaying or preventing Alzheimer’s. To reduce or prevent TAU collection in the brain, Zoghbi and co-workers inhibited about 600 kinases, one after another.(85) An investigation reveals that inhibiting NUAK1 reduces TAU levels. That is to say, NUAK1 stabilizes TAU through phosphorylation, precisely at Ser356. In fruit flies, NUAK1 inhibition suppresses neurodegeneration in TAU-expressing Drosophila melanogaster, and the phenotypes of a tauopathy mouse model are haploinsufficiency rescued by NUAK1. Overall, reducing the total TAU levels is an effective approach for mitigating TAU-mediated neurodegeneration, and it reveals NUAK1 as a unique target for treating neurodegenerative diseases.

    4.2. Ovarian Cancer

    Ovarian cancer, which is common in older women, occurs when an uncontrollable increase in abnormal cells produces a tumor in the female’s reproductive system that forms an ovum. Wang and co-workers investigated NUAK1’s function in ovarian cancer and adjacent normal tissues and observed that it is up-regulated in ovarian cancer tissues compared with that in normal matched tissues.(89) It promotes epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and inhibits microRNA 1181 expression in ovarian cancer cells. Further, in ovarian cancer cells, microRNA 1181 promotes mesenchymal-epithelial transition (MET) and degrades homeobox A10 via targeting its three prime untranslated region (3′-UTR). Therefore, homeobox A10 promotes EMT in ovarian cancer cells, and activation of the NUAK1/microRNA 1181/homeobox A10 axis can be connected with EMT in ovarian cancer. Similarly, Kusakai and co-workers investigated NUAK1’s function in ovarian cancer progression, invasion, and metastasis by using human colon cancer cell lines (SW480, LoVo, SW620, HCT-15, DLD-1, and WiDr) and samples of clinical colon cancers.(86) High NUAK1 expression was detected, and a considerable high expression was identified in the liver metastasis. Additionally, in tumor cells, in situ hybridization examination displayed NUAK1 overexpression. Therefore, the PKB-NUAK1 pathway plays a crucial role in ovarian cancer development.

    4.3. Lung Cancer

    Lung cancer causes controllable multiplication of cells in the lungs. Chen and co-workers investigated NUAK1’s function in the invasion and migration of human NSCLC cell lines.(63) The study revealed that NUAK1 expression is associated with the stage and differentiation of the carcinoma, along with lymph node metastases. That is to say, inhibiting NUAK1 expression through small interfering RNA (siRNA) severely impairs invasion and migration in A549 cell lines. In addition, NUAK1 knock-down suppresses the expression of MMP-9 and MMP-2 and the activation of nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB), which can control the transcription of MMP-9 and MMP-2. Accordingly, in a xenograft mouse model of NSCLCs, NUAK1 knock-down decreases lung metastasis, suggesting that NUAK1 plays a vital function in NSCLC cell invasion and migration. Likewise, Li and co-workers studied NUAK1’s function in NSCLC cells and observed that A549 cell lines, which demonstrate small NUAK1 expression levels, are more sensitive to cisplatin than NCI-H1229 cell lines, which demonstrate large NUAK1 expression levels.(90) Further, NUAK1 knock-down increases the sensitivity of NSCLC cells to cisplatin, and NUAK1 assists EMT in NSCLC cells. Therefore, NUAK1 activation can be clearly linked with EMT in NSCLC cells, revealing that NUAK1 is a promising drug target for regulating EMT in NSCLC cells and combating drug resistance. Similarly, B. Zhang and co-workers observed that NUAK1 is extremely expressed in NSCLC cells and performs a significant role in NSCLC invasion.(41) Moreover, in NSCLC, the miR204 serves as a tumor suppressor by inhibiting NUAK1 expression. Therefore, both miR204 and NUAK1 can act as promising targets for NSCLC treatment.

    4.4. HCC

    In adults, the most common kind of primary liver cancer is HCC. Xu and co-worker proved that NUAKs are an independent prognostic aspect for overall survival in HCC patients.(62) That is to say, both NUAK1 and mRNA protein expression levels in HCC tissues are considerably greater than those in noncancerous (benign) tissues, and the higher NUAK1 expression in HCC is linked with tumor stage, histological differentiation, and tumor size. Further, a higher NUAK1 expression in HCC results in a considerably poor prognosis of patients with HCC. Therefore, NUAK1 can be employed as a unique biomarker and a promising therapeutic target for HCC. Similarly, Liang and co-workers showed that NUAK1 performs a key function in doxorubicin 1 resistance in HCC patient under both hypoxia and normoxia conditions, thus revealing that NUAK1 can be employed as a unique target for resolving HCC chemo-resistance (Figure 8).(91)

    4.5. Glioma

    A glioma is a kind of tumor that begins in the spine or the neuroglia (aka. glial cells or glia) of the brain. Zhang and co-workers have disclosed that NUAKs are overexpressed in glioma cell lines and stimulate invasion of glioma cells by regulating matrix metalloproteinase activation and cytoskeleton rearrangement.(20) In a glioma xenograft mouse model, NUAK1 knock-down was observed to diminish brain invasion, suggesting that NUAK1 has a unique role in bridging two key pathways, viz., LIMK/cofilin and PKB, in glioma tumor cell invasion, as well as in the regulation of cytoskeleton rearrangement. Hence, NUAK1 can be employed as a molecular target for the formation of potent glioma invasion therapy, and as a useful and novel prognostic marker for gliomas.

    4.6. Melanoma

    One important type of skin cancer is melanoma (aka. malignant melanoma) which starts in the cells (melanocytes) that regulate skin pigment. Levy and co-workers studied the function of miRNA-211 in the treatment of melanoma invasion by disruption of cell–cell adhesion.(18) The investigation revealed that miRNA-211 contributes to melanoma adhesion by directly targeting NUAK1. Inhibiting miRNA-211 decreases melanoma adhesion and enhances NUAK1 expression, while up-regulating miRNA-211 restores melanoma adhesion via repression of NUAK1. Hence, miRNA-211 has a vital function in the microphthalmos-related transcription factor (MITF)-based phenotypic plasticity of malignant melanoma, and NUAK1 is a promising target for melanoma treatment.

    4.7. Breast Cancer

    Breast cancer is a disorder in which cells in the breast multiply in an uncontrolled fashion. Chang and co-workers used human breast cancer cell lines to study NUAK1’s function in the metastasis and invasion of cancer.(40) The investigation revealed that NUAK1 enhances the metastatic and invasive potential of MDA-MB-231 cell lines under PKB regulation. The enhancement is linked with growing MT1-MMP, MMP-9, and MMP-2 expression. Moreover, an in vivo investigation revealed that NUAK1-transfected breast cancer cells grow faster and have higher pulmonary metastasis than its parental counterparts.

    4.8. Pancreatic Cancer

    Pancreatic cancer involves the development of malignant (cancerous) cells in the pancreas tissues. Huang and co-workers described that NUAK1 expression is particularly up-regulated in pancreatic cancer, and that it stimulates the invasion, migration, and proliferation of MIA-Pa-Ca-2 pancreatic cancer cell lines by directly targeting NUAK1.(92) NUAK1 also stimulates the tumorigenesis, metastasis, and invasion, and suppresses the necrosis of PANC-1 human pancreatic cancer cell lines.(28) Therefore, NUAK1, as an oncogene, can be a useful target therapy for pancreatic cancer treatment.

    4.9. Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma

    Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) originates in the cells inside the bile ducts; both outside and inside the liver. Cheng and co-workers examined NUAK1’s function by assessing microRNA-145 in ICC.(93) The Investigation revealed that the level of microRNA-145 is considerably reduced in ICC cell lines and tissue, which is linked with an increment in NUAK1 expression. Precisely, NUAK1 is observed to be a direct target of microRNA-145 regulation, and accordingly, the overexpression of microRNA-145 in ICC cells inhibits invasion, growth, and proliferation via suppressing NUAK1 expression, which is directly linked with a decrease in matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) protein expression and PKB signaling. Further, microRNA-145 behaves as a tumor suppressor by directly controlling NUAK1 expression, which modulates MMP expression as well as PKB/FOXO1 signaling, thus inhibiting progression of ICC. Overall, microRNA-145 can be valuable for targeted therapy and clinical diagnosis of ICC.

    4.10. Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

    Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is a collection of tumors arising in the larynx, oropharynx, and oral cavity, respectively. It has a large capability for invasion. Obayashi and co-workers studied the function of microRNA-203 in invasion and EMT induction in HNSCC.(94) It was revealed that microRNA-203 is down-regulated during EMT induction, and ectopic overexpression of microRNA-203 suppresses the invasion and induces MET in HNSCC cell lines. Interestingly, NUAK1 was found to be a potent target gene of microRNA-203 by cyclopedic examination using antiargonaute-2 antibody. Enlarged NUAK1 expression is found during EMT induction, whereas the ectopic expression of microRNA-203 delays EMT induction by suppressing NUAK1 expression. Furthermore, NUAK1 overexpression promotes the invasion of HNSCC cell lines. Notably, NUAK1 expression is strongly associated with lymph node metastasis, poor differentiation, and aggressive invasion patterns. Briefly, microRNA-203 has a tumor-suppressing function in invasion and EMT induction by targeting NUAK1 in HNSCC, thus revealing microRNA-203 as a promising therapeutic and diagnostic target for treating HNSCC patients.

    4.11. Multiple Myeloma

    Multiple myeloma (MM), aka. plasma cell myeloma, is a tumor of plasma cells, a kind of white blood cell which generally forms antibodies. Parekh and co-workers disclosed a novel regulatory mechanism for regulating MM with immediate translational relevance by employing small organic NUAK1 inhibitor.(55) That is to say, selective NUAK1 inhibition is observed to be a useful approach to target cellular proliferation in MM. In other words, ON-123300 2, a dual NUAK1/CDK4 inhibitor, is found to have specific and potent antimyeloma activity, whose inhibiting NUAK1 potency is lethal in MM cell lines in vivo and in vitro, whereas sparing normal healthy B-cell lines (Figure 8). Also, NUAK1-specific siRNAs or ON-123300-based NUAK1 inhibition results in up-regulation of the AMPK kinase cascade and inhibition of the mTOR/S6K pathway. AMPK up-regulation results in destabilization of steady-state MYC protein and enhanced SIRT1 levels.

    4.12. Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

    Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), commonly known as nasopharyngeal cancer, is a tumor in which malignant (cancerous) cells develop in the tissues of the nasopharynx. Liu and Lan investigated how lncRNA SNHG1 (long noncoding RNA small nucleolar RNA host gene 1) affects the aggressiveness of NPC cell lines.(95) The investigation revealed that SNHG1 increases NUAK1 expression, negatively regulates microRNA-145–5p expression, and promotes NPC cell migration and invasion, thus revealing that the SNHG1/microRNA-145-5p/NUAK1 axis plays a vital part in nasopharyngeal cancer, and therefore, can act as a significant target for NPC therapy. Likewise, Xu and co-workers also found excessively high NUAK1 expression in NPC tissues at mRNA levels.(96) Statistical examination reveals that NUAK1 expression is associated with WHO histological type and maximum neck lymph node diameter. Further, there is clinical correlation between NUAK1 up-regulation in NPC and DFS. Also, the NUAK1 expression is highly correlated with DFS and OS in patients with late-stage tumor.

    4.13. Bladder Cancer (BC)

    BC is a cancer arising from the tissues of the urinary bladder. Wang and co-workers disclosed that SNHG-6 overexpression induces EMT and promotes the invasion and migration abilities of BC cell lines.(97) Alternatively, SNHG-6 induces EMT of BC cell lines by up-regulating Snail1/2 expression levels, and it regulates BC cell invasion and migration via tumor suppressive human hsa-miR-125b-5p and its target gene NUAK1. Furthermore, SNHG-6 is negatively associated with human hsa-miR-125b-5p expression and positively associated with Snail1/2 expression in BC specimens. Briefly, SNHG-6 promotes BC cell invasion and migration partly via the human hsa-miR-125b-5p/Snail1/2/NUAK1 pathway. Hence, SNHG-6 can be a promising biomarker in BC, and targeting human hsa-miR-125b-5p/Snail1/2/NUAK1 axis can be a potential therapeutic method for patients with BC.

    4.14. Gastric Cancer

    Gastric cancer (GC), aka. stomach cancer, is cancer that begins from the lining of the stomach. Liu and co-workers explored the involvement of NUAK1 in GC metastasis and invasion, using nude mice, human GC cell lines, and clinical samples of patients.(98) The study revealed that NUAK1 expression is enhanced and positively associated with poor prognosis in GC patients, EMT-related markers, and metastasis. Precisely, knock-down of NUAK1 expression highly suppresses GC cells metastasis and invasion by controlling EMT, instead of proliferation in vivo and in vitro. Knock-down of NUAK1 expression in GC cell lines leads to down-regulation of the mTOR/phospho-p70S6K signals, SIP1, and Slug. In the same context, Ye and co-workers investigated the prognostic value of NUAK1 protein in GC and found that the up-regulated expression of NUAK1 protein is an interpreter of various aggressive tumor behaviors; for example, postoperational recurrence and advanced clinical stage in patients with stomach cancer.(99) Consequently, large NUAK1 expression identifies patients at high risk. Therefore, NUAK1 can be promising therapeutic target for patients with GC.

    4.15. Colorectal Cancer

    Colorectal cancer (CRC), i.e., colon cancer, bowel cancer, or rectal cancer, involves cancer formation in the rectum or colon. Port and co-workers showed that NUAK1 is overexpressed in human CRC and that high expression of NUAK1 is associated with decreased overall survival.(100) Further, NUAK1 is desired for both maintenance and initiation of autochthonous colorectal tumors, and it assists nuclear translocation of the antioxidant master regulator nuclear factor erythroid 2-type factor-2 (NRF2). Thus, inhibition or depletion of NUAK1 renders human CRC cell lines and murine CR tumors susceptible to oxidative stress-induced cell death, thus suggesting that transient NUAK1 inhibition can deliver an effective and safe means to cure human CRC via disruption of intrinsic antioxidant defenses. Kusakai and co-workers also studied NUAK1’s function in the metastasis, invasion, and progression of CRC by using human CRC cell lines (SW480, LoVo, SW620, HCT-15, DLD-1, and WiDr) and samples of clinical CRC and their metastasis. They revealed that the PKB-NUAK1 pathway performs significant roles in the progression of CRC.(86)

    4.16. Omphalocele (Exomphalos)

    Efforts to recognize novel genes involved in mouse brain development resulted in the formation of a global NUAK1 knockout, which was then named omphalocele kinase 1 (OMPHK1), owing to the phenotype generated by the gene deletion.(32) The main phenotype is in the ventral body wall (VBW), in spite of the interest in the gene attributed to its expression in the brain. The knockout was produced by introducing the lacZ gene after the translation initiation site to examine the expression by βgal staining, and it was verified by RT-PCR. No live NUAK1 knockout embryos were born, and the embryos displayed an exomphalos phenotype by embryonic day (ED) 14.5, displaying it far more noticeably by day 18.5.(15) NUAK1 was expressed in both abdominal and sternal bands; however, the former failed to fuse appropriately across the central abdomen. Before embryonic day 12.5, the knockout embryos were normal, and the region taken by the primary body wall expresses NUAK1.(15) Pathways involved in mediating this phenotype were not investigated, and numerous screening analysis previously showed that other kinases are expressed in the VBW.(101) An exomphalos phenotype is a defect in the abdominal wall, in which a defect in the closure of the abdominal wall causes several internal organs to remain outside the abdomen, covered by a membrane. These types of malformations are one of the foremost kinds of physical birth defects in human and exist in almost one in every 4000–2000 live births.(102) Humans have a high percentage of mortality (i.e., around 25%) and usually other related pathologies; for example, neural tube defects. Chromosomal abnormalities have been noticed in a small number of human cases; however, the precise pathways involved in this phenotype are unclear.(102) Certain cases have been associated with trisomy 13(103) and trisomy 18.(104) NUAK1 is situated on human chromosome 12, and hence, it is unlikely that the exomphalos phenotype has the similar underlying reason that generates the effect in NUAK1 knockout mouse. Recent studies on mouse knockouts have also presented certain evidence about the pathways involved, as the following transgenic models all show VBW defects: ROCK-I/ROCK-II double knockout,(105) Mab21l2,(106) Tgfβ2/β3 double mutant,(107) Hoxb2/b4 double mutant,(108) and AP-2α.(109) Some recent reports have also outlined that mouse global knockout of NUAK1 and NUAK2 shows the same embryonic lethality attributed to spina bifida, facial clefting, and exencephaly, as well as failure of the VBW to close. The investigation has shown an alternation in the accumulation of several cytoskeletal components, including phosphorylated F-actin, MLC, and cortactin in the forming neural plate, demonstrating possible downstream targets.(16,32)

    5. Inhibiting NUAK Isoforms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    5.1. NUAK Isoforms in Disease and Importance of NUAK Isoform Inhibition

    Alterations in NUAK isoforms have been causally connected to diverse pathological disorders, especially infectious disorders, Alzheimer’s disease, and tumors and multiple cancers, including HCC,(62) glioma, breast,(20,40) melanoma,(18) colorectal,(86) ovarian,(110−112) and NSCLC,(91) among others.(60) Therefore, NUAK isoforms have shown very promising prospects for targeted treatment using inhibitors. Furthermore, in many ways, NUAK isoforms are ideal targets for cancer drug development. They have a well-defined ATP-binding pocket where small molecules can tightly bind and are amenable for crystal structures with bound inhibitors, which makes inhibition/binding assays relatively easy to perform. For these reasons and others, most therapeutic kinase inhibitors have been developed using target-based approaches.(113) However, developing NUAK inhibitor-based cancer drugs with target-based screening has its own challenges and limitations. First, the biochemical assays of a target may not accurately model the target’s behavior in the cell, where the presence of cofactors or post-translational modifications can affect inhibitor binding.(114) In addition, many of these biochemical assays only use a single domain of multidomain complexes owing to the difficulty involved in purifying many full-length proteins. In the case of kinase biochemical assays, usually, only the kinase domain is used despite the fact that many kinases possess autoregulatory domains.(115) However, in recent years, numerous breakthroughs have been achieved in the discovery of small molecules as highly potent inhibitors of NUAK isoforms (Table 1). This section will highlight the recent progress in the formation of NUAKs inhibitors.
    Table 1. Inhibitors Showing NUAK1 (ARK5) and NUAK2 (SNARK) Activities
    inhibitor nameprimary targetsmajor off-target effectsstring value IC50eref
    ON-123300 2hNUAK1 and CDK4CDK6, FLT3, and FYN4.95 nMa(55,124)
    XMD-1842 3hNUAK1Aurora A/B and NUAK230 nMa(10,116)
    XMD-1883 4hNUAK1ABL, DDR2, Lck, CLK2, Src, and JAK217 nMa(117)
    HTH-010015 5hNUAK1 and NUAK2no major off-targets found100 nMa(10)
    LRRK2in1 6iLRRK2CHEK2 and NUAK147% at 10 μM conc.f; 3.67 μMj; 5 μMk(118)
    JWE-071 7hNUAK1ABL, Aurora A, Src, JAK2 and amidst6 nMa(117)
    XMD-17-51 8hNUAK1Aurora A & B, Src, JAK2 and ABL1.5 nMa(10)
    DLW-01-125-01 9hNUAK1Aurora A & B, FGFR and Src, ABL7 nMa(117)
    DLW-01-122-01 10hNUAK1 and Aurora A & BNUAK215 nMa(117)
    MRT199665 11iSIK isoformsNUAK and MARK isoforms3 nMa, 120 nMc(5)
    WZ4074 12hNUAK1BTK, HER4, and MLK isoforms33 nMa(117)
    TPX-0005 (aka. Repotrectinib) 13iROS1, RTKA, TRKB, TRKC, and JAK2ALK and NUAK13.70 nMa(145)
    BAY-880 14hNUAK1no off-targets reported96% at 1 μM conc.f(76)
    MRX6313 (aka. UNC2025) 15iMER and FLT3TYRO3, AXL, TRKA, NUAK1, TRKC, QIK, and SIK7.97 nMa(120)
    BI-885578 16iIGF-1R and InsRCLK2, FER, IRAK1, PRKCN, FES, PTK2, and NUAK10.411 μMa(146)
    HTH-02-006 17hNUAK2NUAK1126 nMc(71)
    WZ4003 18hNUAK1 and NUAK2no major off-targets found20 nMa, 100 nMc(10)
    HMSL10085 19hNUAK1IGFR, BTK, and HER4. HMSL1008525 nMa(117)
    BAY-1000394 20iCDKsFLT4, NUAK1, Mst2, MLK1, JAK2, ARK1, and CDK4<10 nMa(125)
    BX-795 21hNUAK1MARK isoforms, JAK2, GCK and CDK25 nMa(127)
    MRT67307 22iIKKε and TBK1, ULK1, and ULK2MARK, NUAK, and SIK isoforms230 nMa, 2600 nMc(5)
    SJB4-115 23hNUAK1JAK2, SIK2, ULK1, Lck, Src, TrkA, and ERK867 nMa(117)
    Fedratinib (aka. SAR302503, TG101348) 24iJAK2, FLT3, and RETTSF1, DAPK3, ACV-R1, FGF-R1 V561M, MUSK, FAK, ACK1, and NUAK150%f and 53%l at 1 μM conc.(128)
    cerdulatinib 25iJAK, SYK, and TYK2NUAK1 and MST14.00 nMa(129,130)
    NVP-TAE684 26iNPM-ALKPLK4, BMPR1B, NUAK isoforms, PYK2, and FER13 nMb, 1.2 nMd(132)
    CEP-28122 27iALKNUAK1, Rsk2, Rsk3, and Rsk426 ± 3.00 nMa(133)
    Brigatinib (AP26113) 28iALK, EGFR, FLT3, IGF-1R, and ROS1FER, FLT3, FES, FAK, BRK, CHK2, and NUAK147 nMa(134)
    indolinone 29iMELKAMPK, NUAK1, CHK1, CAMKK2, and ERK28.60 ± 1.60 nMm(135)
    indolinone 30iMELKAMPK, NUAK1, CHK1, CAMKK2, and ERK211 ± 0.860 nMm(135)
    indolinone 31iMELKAMPK, NUAK1, CHK1, CAMKK2, and ERK21.70 ± 0.170 nMm(135)
    Sunitinib 32iRTKsFLT3, FLT3-ITD, FLT3-Asp835, and NUAK148 nMa(115,136)
    indole 33iAurora BNUAK1, TrKA, TAK1, and Gck1.40 nMa(137)
    TAK-901 34iAurora A/B, JAK3 and c-SRCCLK2, FGR, LRRK2, FLT3, FYN, ARG, AXL, HCK, and NUAK19.1 nMa(138)
    benzo[e]pyridoindolone 35iAURKsNUAK1, SIK2 and MELK4.80 ± 0.4 nMa(139)
    A7 36iCK2 and CDK2Aurora A, Rock II and NUAK127%f,g(140)
    A22 37iMKK1, HIPK isoforms, CDK isoforms, and PDK1MKK1, GSK3b, and NUAK116%f,g(140)
    A27 38iNek2A and NUAK1not reported49%f,g(140)
    A26 39iCDK2 and NUAK1not reported24%f,g(140)
    prexasertib 40iCHK1 and CHK2RSK1, MELK, SIK, BRSK2 and NUAK164 nMa(141)
    AZ-SHN-722 41iTrkAMST2, NUAK1, and Aurora A34.9 nMa(142)
    AZ960 42iJAK2TrkA, Aurora-A, and NUAK135% at 0.01 μm conc.f(143)
    imidazole 43iJAK isoforms and Tyk2NUAK1 and BRSK12.00 nMa(144)
    GSK461364 44iPLK1NUAK2 and LOK23 nMd(115)
    a

    IC50 for NUAK1.

    b

    Kd for NUAK1.

    c

    IC50 for NUAK2.

    d

    Kd for NUAK2.

    e

    Based on in vitro and/or in vivo phosphorylation data.

    f

    Percentage of residual kinase activity of NUAK1 at a specific concentration relative to control.

    g

    According to original publication, the % value of around 50 corresponds to an IC50 of 10 μM.

    h

    The compound being described is found in a screen against the NUAKs.

    i

    The compound being described is found to inhibit the NUAKs as off targets from a different kinase inhibitor.

    j

    Biochemical NUAK1 assay IC50 (Invitrogen).

    k

    Biochemical NUAK1 assay IC50 (Dundee).

    l

    Percentage of residual kinase activity of NUAK2.

    m

    Ki for NUAK1.

    5.2. Small Molecules as Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    5.2.1. Seven-Membered Ring Fused Pyrimidine Derivatives as Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    XMD-1842 3 exhibits high activity for NUAK1 in vitro with an IC50 value of 30 nM, whereas NUAK1 [A195T] mutant is 50-fold more resistant toward it. Further, in HEK293 cells, it is found to inhibit Ser445 phosphorylation on MYPT1 with an IC50 value of 10 μM.(10,116) The kinase specificity panel for XMD-1842 3 shows that it also potentially inhibits Aurora B (Figure 9). Moreover, IC50 examination of 3 for the Aurora kinases revealed that the compound strongly inhibited Aurora C with an IC50 of 120 nM and Aurora B with an IC50 of 54 nM. In related development, XMD-1843 4 is a less specific NUAK1 inhibitor (IC50 value of 17 nM) with off-target inhibition of JAK2, Src, CLK2, Lck, DDR2, and ABL.(117) Interestingly, HTH-01-015 5, a hybrid of XMD-1843 4 and XMD-1842 3, is a highly potent NUAK1 inhibitor with IC50 value of 100 nM and >100 times selectivity over NUAK2.(116) This compound shows high specificity and does not considerably inhibit the potency of other 139 kinases, including the AMPK class members. In contrast, LRRK2in1 6 is a strong and extremely selective LRRK2 inhibitor (Figure 9) that has off-target effects on NUAK1. LRRK2in1 6 inhibits NUAK1 in vitro by about 47% with a concentration of 10 μM.(118) In terms of kinome selectivity, JWE-071 7 is a relatively better NUAK1 inhibitor than LRRK2in1 6, XMD-1842 3, and XMD-1843 4, and it also has potent NUAK1 inhibitory activity with IC50 value of 6 nM.(117) The main off-targets of 7 are Src, ABL, JAK2, and Aurora A. Italso displays some inhibitory potency on BRSK1, AMPK, and certain MARK family members. Together with 7, the closely related compound XMD-17-51 8 also has a higher affinity for NUAK1, with an IC50 value of 1.5 nM, and inhibits the phosphorylation of Ser445 on MYPT1 with 10-μM concentration in HEK293 cell lines.(10,116) The off-target effects of 8 are similar to those of 7 suppressing ABL, JAK2, Src, and Aurora A and B. Amidst the AMPK class kinases, 8 has reasonable activity on BRSK1, AMPK, and certain MARK family members. DLW-01-125-01 9 has a potency similar to that of XMD-17-51 8 and JWE-071 7 toward NUAK1, with an IC50 of 7 nM, and NUAK1 [A195T] in turn offers over 200-fold more resistance.(117) In comparison with XMD-17-51 8 and JWE-071 7, DLW-01-125-01 9 has relatively low off-target effects on inhibiting Aurora B and Aurora A and displays reasonable inhibition of ABL, Src, and FGFR (Figure 9). By far, DLW-01-122-01 10 is the most selective of all the seven-membered ring fused pyrimidine derivatives series. Its only disadvantage is that it inhibits Aurora B and Aurora A with the same capacity as NUAK1 (IC50 value of 15 nM, with NUAK1 [A195T] IC50 value of 2 μM).(117)

    5.2.2. Five- and Six-Membered Ring Fused Pyrimidines as Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    In the series of five-membered ring fused pyrimidines, MRT199665 11 is a potent pan-SIK inhibitor, with IC50 values of 43 nM, 12 nM, and 110 nM for SIK3, SIK2, and SIK1, respectively (Figure 10). Apart from its potent SIKs inhibiting activities, it is also a relatively good inhibitor of NUAKs, with an IC50 value of 3 nM for NUAK1 and IC50 value of 120 nM for NUAK2; however, its selectivity is far less.(5) In the same line, WZ4074 12 potently inhibits NUAK1 with an IC50 of 33 nM but has several off-targets including HER4, BTK, and some MLK family members.(117) Furthermore, in series, TPX-0005 13, aka. repotrectinib, is a TRK/ROS1/ALK inhibitor with IC50 values of 1.08 nM for ALK (L1196M), 1.26 nM for ALK (G1202R), and 1.01 nM for WT ALK. It is also a good inhibitor of NUAK1 (IC50 = 3.70 nM).(117,119) Very recently, BAY-880 14 is reported as a potent NUAK1 inhibitor that inhibits 96% of its kinase activity at concentration of 1 μM. Investigating BAY-880 14 against a series of 274 kinases displayed that its best target is NUAK1 and showed a tiny number of other kinases that is inhibited by this derivative.(76) Lastly, MRX6313 15, a dual Mer/FLT3 TK inhibitor, inhibits NUAK1 with an IC50 of 7.97 nM.(120)
    There are two members in the series of six-membered ring fused pyrimidine derivatives, viz. ON-123300 2 (aka.7x), and BI-885578 16.(121,122) Biochemical assays indicated that ON-123300 2 is a strong inhibitor of CDK4 (IC50 = 3.9 nM) and NUAK1 (IC50 = 5 nM) and also displays considerable inhibitory activity against FYN (IC50 = 11 nM), RET (IC50 = 9.2 nM), FGFR1 (IC50 = 26 nM), and PDGFRb (IC50 = 26 nM) (Figure 8).(124) Although tumor development in ON-123300-treated xenograft nude mouse models is inhibited over an 18-day period, mice treated with ON-123300 2 did not exhibit signs of toxicity.(123) On the same note, BI-885578 16 is an effective, selective, ATP-competitive IGF-1R/InsR tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) with a Kd of 9 nM/12 nM and an IC50 of 1 nM/1 nM, respectively (Figure 10). Recent investigation has revealed that it also exhibits potency against NUAK1 with an IC50 of 0.411 μM but exhibits numerous off-target influences.(22) In general, this series has many inhibitors with excellent potency, but selectivity is not desirable, except for ON-123300 2 and BAY-880 14, which showed outstanding activity as well as selectivity.

    5.2.3. Substituted n-Phenylpyrimidin-2-amine Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    Very recently, a novel semispecific inhibitor of NUAK2, namely, HTH-02–006 17 (NUAK2 IC50 = 126 nM), has been disclosed, which is observed to show excellent selectivity.(71) WZ4003 18 is one of most well-known NUAK inhibitors, which inhibits both NUAK family members. For NUAK1, it exhibits an IC50 of 20 nM and for NUAK2, the IC50 is 100 nM.(116) This compound shows a high level of selectivity, and besides NUAK1 and NUAK2, it does not considerably inhibit the potency of the other 139 kinases, including members of AMPK-related kinases. In the same context, HMSL10085 19 is an NUAK1 inhibitor with off-target inhibition of HER4, BTK, and IGFR. That is to say, HMSL10085 19 has a comparable NUAK1 IC50 of 25 nM; however, it is less selective.(117) In a related investigation, BAY-1000394 20, a novel cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor for CDK9/7/4/3/2/1 (IC50 = 5–25 nM) that has potent antitumor activity, is found to target NUAK1 with an IC50 < 10 nM.(125) (Figure 11). In conclusion, BAY-1000394 20 is extremely less selective than HTH-02-006 17, WZ4003 18 and HMSL10085 19.

    5.2.4. Substituted Diaminopyrimidine Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    BX-795 21 is an effective and comparatively specific inhibitor of NUAK isoforms,(14,17) which has been primarily described as a PDK1 inhibitor(126) and later as a strong IKKε/TBK1 inhibitor.(127) It has an NUAK1 IC50 of 5 nM and inhibits most of the AMPK subfamily members including some members of MARK class with nanomolar IC50 values.(127) Along the previous, the closely related inhibitor MRT67307 22 also exhibits kinase inhibitory activity (Figure 12). It inhibits TBK1, MARK1-4, IKKε, NUAK1, and NUAK2. For NUAK1 and NUAK2, the IC50 values are 230 nM and 2600 nM, respectively.(5) SJB4-115 23, similar to BX-795 21 and MRT67307 22, potently inhibits NUAK1 using in vitro profiling, with an IC50 of 67 nM (Figure 12). However, compared with HMSL10085 19, SJB4-115 23 is far less selective for NUAK1, demonstrating off-target effects on Src, SIK2, ULK1, Lck, TRKA, ERK8, and JAK2.(117) Fedratinib 24 shows excellent selectivity for JAK2 with an IC50 of 3 nM in cell-free assays, 334 and 35 times more selective for JAK2 versus JAK3 and JAK1. In an interesting study, fedratinib 24 showed inhibition potency toward AMPK family members, including NUAK1 with a percentage kinase activity of 50% (NUAK1) and 53% (NUAk2) at 1 μM concentration.(128) In a similar fashion, cerdulatinib 25, a small molecule which is a dual JAK and SYK inhibitor,(129,130) is also a multikinase inhibitor with effective inhibitory potency against NUAK1 kinase with IC50 of 4.00 nM in ATP and radioactivity assay.(131) Likewise, NVP-TAE684 26 is an extremely powerful and selective ALK inhibitor with an IC50 value of 3 nM, and it also inhibits NUAK1 and NUAK2 with a Kd value equals to 13 nM and 1.2 nM, respectively.(132) Apart from fedratinib 24 and cerdulatinib 25, some other commercial drugs also show activity toward NUAK1 (Figure 12). For example, CEP-28122 27, an extremely selective and potent orally active inhibitor of ALK tyrosine kinase receptor with antitumor potency, presents efficient NUAK1-inhibitory activity with an IC50 of 26 ± 3.00 nM.(133) Furthermore, brigatinib 28 is a tyrosine kinase receptor inhibitor and an antineoplastic agent used in selected forms of advanced NSCLC. Reportedly, this drug targets and inhibits NUAK1 (IC50 = 47 nM).(134) Thus, it can be concluded that fedratinib 24, cerdulatinib 25, NVP-TAE684 26, CEP-28122 27, and brigatinib 28 are not as selective as the BX-795 21 and SJB4-115 23 members of this series. In the case of NUAK2, the inhibitory efficiency of pyrimidine inhibitors toward NUAK2 is high in many cases such as WZ4003 18 and NVP-TAE684 26; however, with the exception of 17 and 18, all other members are less selective.

    5.2.5. Indole Derivatives as Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    In this series, indolinone derivatives 29, 30, and 31 have been shown to inhibit NUAK1 potency in vitro with nanomolar Ki values (8.60 ± 1.60 nM, 11 ± 0.860 nM, and 1.70 ± 0.170 nM, respectively), and these derivatives have off-target effects on other AMPK family members.(135) Along the others, the closely related receptor TKIs, viz. sunitinib 32 has been reported to inhibit NUAK1 with a nanomolar IC50 value (48 nM) (Figure 13).(115,136) Subsequently, biochemical assays indicate that the indole derivative (namely, C14) 33 is a strong inhibitor of NUAK1 (IC50 = 1.40 nM).(137) TAK-901 34, a multitargeted Aurora inhibitor, targets NUAK1 with IC50 of 9.1 nM as per ATP assay.(138) Along the same line, benzo[e]pyridoindolone derivative 35 is a potent inhibitor of AMPKs, including NUAK1 with an IC50 of 4.80 ± 0.400 nM, as determined using cell-free assays.(139) Overall, there are many indole-based inhibitors of NUAK1 with excellent potency; however, none of them are appropriate in terms of selectivity (Table 1).

    5.2.6. Thiazole-Cored Inhibitors of NUAK Isoforms

    Thiazole derivatives were developed to possess better specificity but still inhibit other AMPK family members. To be more precise, A7 36 is a NUAK1 inhibitor with 27% residual kinase activity, while A22 37 has very less% residual activity (16%). Both inhibitors also have many off-target activities. On the same note, the NUAK1 percentage residual activity of A27 38 is 49% and of A26 39 is 24% (Figure 14). According to original publication, a % value of around 50 corresponds to an IC50 of 10 μM.(140) In summary, this class has less selectivity especially in the case of 36 and 37 but a good IC50 value.

    5.2.7. Inhibitory Activity of Pyrazole- and Imidazole-Containing Compounds

    In the series of pyrazole-cored inhibitors, there are three members, viz. prexasertib 40, SHN-722 41, and AZ960 42. In detail, prexasertib 40, a potent, selective, and ATP-competitive CHK1 inhibitor, has a relatively moderate NUAK1 IC50 value (64 nM) with off-target effects on other AMPK-related kinase family members (Figure 15).(141) Likewise, AZ-SHN-722 41 strongly inhibits NUAK1 with an IC50 = 34.9 nM but exhibits several off-target effects on other family members of AMPK-related kinases.(142) Further, AZ960 42 is an effective JAK2 inhibitor with off-target effects mainly against TrkA, Aurora-A, NUAK1 and ALK. For NUAK1, percentage of residual kinase activity of NUAK1 is 35%, 6%, and 3% at a concentration 0.01, 0.10, and 1.0 μm.(143)
    In the library of imidazole-cored inhibitors, derivative 43 has an excellent NUAK1 IC50 of 2.00 nM, but it is less selective.(144) Furthermore, GSK461364 44 is a selective, potent, and reversible ATP-competitive Plk1 inhibitor (Ki = 2.2 nM) with a good potency to target NUAK2 (Kd = 23 nM).(115) Summarily, in this series, the IC50 values are in the region of 2–64 nM, but all the members are less selective (Figure 15). It can be noted that there is no selective NUAK2 inhibitor in this family, and this family has lower IC50 values of NUAK2 inhibition than the class of pyrimidine-based NUAK2 inhibitors.

    6. Conclusions and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Over the past decade, research on NUAK subtypes (NUAK1 and NUAK2) has received extensive attention because they are involved in a wide range of important cell manipulation areas, controlling and promoting various biological processes, including embryonic development, cell adhesion, cell division, replicative senescence and ploidy, cell migration and invasion, neuronal polarity and axon branching, actin SFs remodeling, metabolic homeostasis, cell proliferation, survival of MYC-overexpressing cells, maintaining skeletal muscle mass and muscle growth, glycogen synthesis and carbohydrate metabolism, and TAU stability. Consequently, these processes become abnormal and lead to a large number of disorders when NUAK1 and NUAK2 function abnormally. Therefore, NUAK isoforms are potential interesting therapeutic targets to treat the following diseases: (i) neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer’s, dementia, and tauopathy; (ii) tumors and multiple cancers, such as HCC, NSCLC, ovarian cancer, glioma, metastatic melanoma, breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, MM, neck and head squamous cell carcinoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, bladder cancer, GC (stomach cancer), and colorectal cancer; and (iii) ALM, DM, and obesity together with increased hyperglycemia, fat mass, and hyperinsulinemia. Also, NUAK1 and NUAK2 are frequent targets of multiple microRNAs which are commonly lost during the progression to metastatic disorder.
